definition[0]: used to show that you are talking about a particular thing or person that has already been mentioned, is already known about, or is the only one
example[1]: I ordered a pizza and salad. The pizza was nice but the salad was disgusting.
example[2]: the tallest building in the world
example[4]: The prime minister has intervened personally.
example[5]: Elections will be held later in the year  (=this year).
example[6]: How are all the family  (=your family)?
definition[1]: used before nouns referring to actions and changes when they are followed by ‘of’
example[7]: the growth of the steel industry
definition[2]: used when you are about to make it clear which person or thing you mean
example[9]: That’s the school that Terry went to.
example[10]: She laughed at the birthday card from Myra.
definition[3]: used before the name of a family in the plural to refer to all the members of that family
example[11]: The Johnsons had lived in this house for many years.
definition[4]: used to refer to something that everyone knows because it is part of our natural environment or part of daily life
example[13]: I looked out into the darkness.
example[14]: Sometimes the traffic kept her awake at night.
definition[5]: used before a singular noun to refer to a type of institution, shop, system etc
example[16]: You used to buy them from the chemist.
example[17]: I heard it on the radio.
example[18]: I’ll put it in the mail for you today.
definition[6]: used to refer to a part of someone’s body
example[19]: Lieutenant Taylor was wounded in the knee.
example[20]: How’s the ankle? Is it still hurting?
definition[7]: used before an adjective to make it into a plural noun when you are referring to all the people that the adjective describes
example[21]: She devoted her life to helping the poor.
example[23]: wars between the English and the French
definition[8]: used before an adjective to make it into a noun when you are referring to the particular kind of situation or thing that the adjective describes
example[24]: Come on now, that’s asking for the impossible.
example[25]: fantasy movies that make the unreal seem real
definition[9]: used before a singular noun when you are referring to a particular type of thing or person in a general way
example[26]: The tiger is without doubt the most magnificent of the big cats.
example[27]: The computer has changed everyone’s lives in so many ways.
definition[10]: used to refer to a period of time, especially a period of 10 or 100 years
example[32]: In the thirties unemployment was widespread.
example[34]: The battle took place on March the 21st, 1940.
example[35]: Shall we meet on the twelfth?
definition[12]: enough of something for a particular purpose
example[36]: I haven’t the time to talk just now.
example[37]: Eric didn’t even have the common sense to send for a doctor.
definition[13]: used to say which type of musical instrument someone plays
definition[14]: used to refer to a type of sport or a sports event, especially in athletics or swimming
example[41]: She swam up and down, practising the crawl.
definition[15]: used before a word or phrase that describes someone or something when you are angry, jealous, surprised etc
example[42]: He’s stolen my parking space, the bastard!
example[43]: I can’t get this carton open, the stupid thing.
example[44]: ‘Jamie’s won a holiday in Hawaii.’ ‘The lucky devil!’
definition[16]: used to emphasize that the person, place, or thing you are mentioning is the famous one, or the best or most fashionable one. ‘The’ is pronounced strongly or written in a special way
example[45]: ‘Elizabeth Taylor was there.’ ‘Not the Elizabeth Taylor, surely?’
example[46]: Miami is THE place for girls who like to live life to the full.
definition[17]: used before the names of certain common illnesses
example[47]: If one of the children got the measles, we all got the measles.
explanation[0]: Don’t use the with uncountable or plural nouns to talk about a general type of thing You say
explanation[1]: Don’t use the with the name of a language You say
explanation[2]: Don’t use the with school, prison, college, university, or church when you are talking about them in a general way You say
example[52]: She spent a year in prison
explanation[3]: You don’t use the with times and months, or normally with days You say
explanation[4]: You don’t normally use the with meals You say
explanation[5]: You don’t normally use the with the name of a place You say
explanation[6]: Use the when you are talking about something specific or something that the reader or listener already knows about You say
example[61]: I didn’t like the music in the film
example[62]: All the computers  (=the computers in this building) are down
example[63]: They go to the school in the village
explanation[7]: Use the with days when saying which specific one you mean You say
explanation[8]: Some places have the as part of their name
definition[18]: used before two comparative adjectives or adverbs to show that the degree of one event or situation is related to the degree of another one
example[70]: The more he eats the fatter he gets.
example[71]: ‘When do you want it?’ ‘The sooner the better.’
definition[19]: used before an adjective or adverb to emphasize that something is bigger, better etc than all others, or as big, good etc as it is possible for it to be
example[73]: I had the worst headache last night.
